Article: For those of us who donât live there, China is more a concept than a palpable reality. We acknowledge its place in the world as a huge market, a colossal population, and a source of products that pour into our markets in often overwhelming volume at astounding speed. But when we focus on why China does what it does â and who makes its decisions â the awakened dragon of the Far East remains a mystery to most of us. Once you step inside China and talk to a few folks, including local executives, colleagues, suppliers, competitors, shopkeepers or taxi drivers, China begins to form âfaces,â even though they donât provide full understanding of everything thatâs going on. This is what happens when we travel, not just to curious tourists and reporters like me, but also the preoccupied head honchos at global companies. Aspencore, publisher of EE Times, brought a bunch of these honchos together this month at the inaugural Global CEO Summit in Shenzhen. I was one of the lucky participants, thrilled to see 1,000 people packed into a huge hotel ballroom. The event was also broadcast live. More than 800 people packed the ballroom at Global CEO Summit in Shenzhen on Nov. 8, 2018. (Photo: Aspencore)  As the summit proceeded, I hoped that those who traveled all the way to Shenzhen to speak and listen appreciated more than just a big audience. I wanted them to benefit even more from their face-to-face meetingsÂ â in casual settings over cocktails, coffee, lunch and dinner â with fellow CEOs and speakers. In these contacts, clients, partners, customers and even rivals begin to recognize one another as people beyond their titles and executive roles. Itâs a chance to size them up and share ideas and argue or agree instead of thinking of these corporate peers in solely transactional terms. For a lowly reporter like myself, this conference was a chance to gather up âdeep backgroundâ about whatâs going onÂ â or not going on â in the industry I cover. I found two CEOs from Europe who had to go all the way to Shenzhen to meet each other face-to-face for the first time. I overheard CEOs rather humbly asking for introductions to other executives, and I spotted several of them huddled at the bar at the end of the night, although I had no idea what they were talking about. It was like summer camp for suits. Paul Bourdre, Soitec CEO (center) with Maurice Geraets, managing director at NXP (right) during a coffee break at the Global CEO Summit (Photo: Aspencore)  Worsening trade relations  Some of the impromptu small talk heard in these impromptu sessions included hints that Chinese carmakers want new automotive chips. I came across clues about the areas in which China is looking for potential investment and is worrying about the tightening of foreign investmentÂ â especially from ChinaÂ â into U.S. companies. There was lots of talk about how the U.S.-China trade war is already affecting their customersâ customers.Â  For example, in the executive round table I moderated at the Summit, many panelists tried hard not to dwell on the escalating tension between China and the Trump White House. They insisted that they werenât worried. Yet, privately over cocktails, our Taiwan EE Times editor confirmed that the trade war, despite its limited impact on data centers in the United States, is already prompting server makers to consider moving production facilities out of China. Â  A Taiwan memory maker, for example, acknowledged that its customers making PC motherboards and servers are planning to save costs by moving their manufacturing back to Taiwan or to ASEAN countries such as Vietnam, Malaysia or Indonesia. But this is easier said than done. Some of these companies arenât exactly satisfied with the infrastructure and the pool of qualified laborers in ASEAN countries. Prof. JosÃ© Franca talking to a Chinese summit participant during a coffee break. (Photo: Aspencore)  Not just CFIUS, but now FIRRMA  Others brought up the Trump administrationâs new ârigorous review systemâ aimed primarily at preventing Chinese access to sensitive American technology. While the Committee on Foreign Investment in the United States (CFIUS) is concerned with M&A activities, the Foreign Investment Risk Review Modernization Act of 2018 (FIRRMA) is a new vehicle that will allow the U.S. to block a much broader array of foreign transactions deemed threats to national security. These include âminority stakesâ and âjoint venturesâ in technology, telecommunications and other cutting-edge companies. As one VC explained to me in Shanghai, this regulation could have a chilling effect on U.S. businesses seeking foreign investment and might erect more hurdles for transactions. On one hand, Xilinx CEO Victor Peng boasted during cocktails about his companyâs recent acquisition of DeePhi Technology Co., a Beijing-based machine- learning startup. His point was that itâs not China investing in the U.S., but the other way around. On another hand, newer and broader restrictions on Chinese investment in U.S. companies will likely make it more difficult for U.S. and Chinese companies to deal in one anotherâs high-tech sectors. Seismic changes in the electronics industry  This yearâs Global CEO Summit took place not only during heightened political tension between the U.S. and China, but while the semiconductor industry is undergoing seismic changes. A host of transformative events affecting the electronics industry include the substantial slowdown of Mooreâs Law, calls for heterogeneous integration, the limited availability of finer geometry in CMOS process technologies, the proliferation of AI where conventional computer architecture no longer holds, the collapse of an abstraction layer that used to separate software from hardware architecture, the emergence of RISC-V (ARM wonât be the only game in town),Â  and the rapid growth of electronics content in EVs and AVs. The confluence of these fundamental shifts in the industry presents China with a clean slate and clear field to achieve equal status with the West, even if it fails to totally leapfrog its Western rivals. For companies in the United States and in Europe, Chinaâs opportunity poses a critical need to devise new strategies, form new alliances and find a path to collaborate with Chinese engineering community. At the very least, Western companies must resolve to at least understand Chinaâs intentions not as an inscrutable monolith, but one Chinese company at a time. Executives from the global semiconductor industry on the front row seats. From left to right: Tyson Tuttle, Silicon Labs CEO; Daniel Cooley, SVP at Silicon Labs; Charles Tan, President of China Electronics Distribution Association; Sassine Ghazi, co-general manager of the design group at Synopsys; Paul Boudre, Soitec CEO (Photo: Aspencore)  All of us can theorize about the Middle Kingdom âtil hell freezes over. But as the Shenzhen Summit proved, meeting fellow engineers and executives in China â not to mention the odd cab driver (who can now talk to you via translate app on their phone) â is a far more effective way to move from speculation to action. â Junko Yoshida, Global Co-Editor-In-Chief, AspenCore Media, Chief International Correspondent, EE Times
